sections.title: Forms

pages.title: Entering English and Georgian Content
pages.summary: The data portal allows you to enter content in multiple languages. This guide will help explain how to enter the content of different languages.
pages.content:
Introduction

Many of the forms in the data portal allow you to enter content in multiple languages. This is done by grouping each field that can be in multiple languages into a tabular block. Each tab contains the exact same fields, the only difference is what language the content should be entered in.

The image below shows two possible languages for the Title form field - English and Georgian (ქართული).

In the above image, the English tab is currently active, which is indicated by the tab's white background. Below is an image of what it looks like when the Georgian tab is active.

Default Language and Entering Required Fields

Many of these multiple language fields are required fields, however only one language needs to have values in the required fields in order for the form to save. That language that is required is the language in the first tab. For instance, in the following image, the English language required field of Title must be entered in order for the form to save.

Entering Only One Language

Since only one language is required, it may be tempting to only enter the one required language and not enter the other language(s). There is a consequence of this action that you should be aware of.

Let's say that you are entering text for the top of the Contact page and that you only enter the English text. When you access the English version of the data portal, you will see the English text. However, when you access the Georgian version of the site, since there is no Georgian text for the Contact page, the English text will be shown. This means that if that requested language does not have content, then the language from the first tab will be shown instead. This will result in a page with multiple languages on it, which is not ideal.

So in the ideal situation, all languages should be entered so that no page will have multiple languages on it.

Choosing Languages for Datasets and Time Series

For most of the data portal forms with multiple language fields, there will always be a tab for English and Georgian. However, the forms to add a Datsaet, Time Series, and Shapeset work slightly differently.

In these forms, you get to choose which languages you want to publish the content in, as seen in the image below from the Dataset form.

This form has two fields for choosing the language:

  • Language of Dataset - select one or more languages
  • Default Language - select which of the languages from the Language of Dataset field is the default language

Selecting a Default Language indicates which language to show by default if the user has not selected a language. It also indicates which required form fields in the language tab must be entered in order for the form to be saved. The Default Language will be in the first tab and a star icon will be added to the tab to help visually indicate that this is the Default Language.

When you add more languages, the tab for that language will automatically appear. In the following image, the Georgian language has been added in the Language of Dataset field and a Georgian tab is now visible.

Now if you change the Default Language to Georgian, you will see below how the first tab is now the Georgian tab.

To be clear, you are not limited to just the English and Georgian languages. You can select from over 60 languages as see below.

What Choosing a Language Allows You To Do

When you choose one or more languages for a Dataset and Time Series, you are indicating to the data portal what languages the data can be translated into. For instance, if you choose English, Georgian, and Russian this means all of the text for questions, answers, groups, etc. can be translated into all three of these languages.

Entering Only One Language

The same rules apply as in the Entering Only One Language section above.

Let's say you selected the three languages of English, Georgian, and Russian but only enter English text. This means that when someone selects to view the Russian language, they will be shown the English text since no Russian text exists.

So in the ideal situation, all languages should be entered so that no page will have multiple languages on it. However, if you do not have time to translate all of the content, it is strongly advised that you only select the languages that you can translate now and at a later time go back and add in the other languages when you have the text translated.

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the Forms guide book:

  • Validation Errors
  • Form Field Hints

pages.title: Required Fields and Validation Errors
pages.summary: This guide will show how to identify required fields and how to understand validation errors.
pages.content:
Introduction

This guide will show how to identify required fields and how to understand validation errors.

Required Fields

Required fields are indicated by a red * located just after the form field label like the following:

Below is another example that has fields that are both required and not required:

The following fields are marked as required with the red *:

  • Data File
  • Languages of Dataset
  • Default Language

The following fields are not required:

  • Date Started Gathering Data
  • Date Finished Gathering Data
  • Date Released

Validation Errors

If there are any errors when you submit a form, they will be shown at the top of the page, like the following:

The error messages will list the fields that have a problem and indicate what the problem is. For instance, in the above screenshot, the message says that the Data Fiile and English Title cannot be blank, which means that they are required.

Not providing a value for a required field will probably be the most common error. Other possible errors will be if you enter an invalid URL, enter an invalid email address, or upload a file that is not of the correct type (i.e., you upload a word document instead the expected PDF file).

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the Forms guide book:

  • Entering English and Georgian Content
  • Form Field Hints

pages.title: Form Field Hints
pages.summary: Almost every field in every form has a brief summary of text explaining the field. This is called a hint.
pages.content:
Introduction

Almost every field in every form has a brief summary of text explaining the field. This is called a hint. If you do not understand what you are supposed to do with a form field, this hint should give you enough information to enter the correct data into the form field.

The presence of a hint is indicated by a ? icon after the form field label like the following:

The hint is viewed by hovering your mouse over the hint icon like the following:

Next Steps

pages.title: User Roles
pages.summary: The data portal has 4 user roles that control access to the admin, dataset, and time series management pages. This guide will explain the each role.
pages.content:
Introduction

The data portal restricts access to certain sections based on the role that a user has been assigned. Below is a list of each possible role and what that role has access to work with.

Roles

No Role (not logged in)

No role means that the person is not logged in. When a person is not logged in, then they only have access to the pages that are listed in the left-sidebar (i.e., home, datasets, contact, support, etc).

User

When a person creates an account on the site, they are automatically assigned the role of User. In addition to everything a No Role can access, a User can also access the User Settings page where they can change their name, password, etc.

In order for a person to have a more advanced role (i.e., Data Editor or Site Admin), a Site Admin must assign them the role by hand.

Data Editor

In addition to everything a User can access, a Data Editor can access the sections to manage datasets and time series.

The Dataset and Time Series sections are  accessed through the user drop down menu located in the right side of the top navigation bar.

[image]

Site Admin

In addition to everything a Data Editor can access, a Site Admin can access the Admin Section to manage users, categories, text on the site, the guide text, etc. The Site Admin also has the ability to download two spreadsheets:

  • All requests made to download datasets
  • All requests made to the API

The Admin Section is accessed through the user drop down menu located in the right side of the top navigation bar.

[image]

Admin

Admin exists as a backup for Site Admins. In case someone deletes all Site Admin accounts, an Admin can access the data portal and create new Site Admin accounts. The Admin role is only assigned to the developers of the data portal.

This means that when a Site Admin access the form to manage User roles, they will only see the roles for User, Data Editor, and Site Admin. Site Admins are not allowed to assign the role of Admin.

[image of user form for site admin and admin]

pages.title: Mass Changes Via Spreadsheet
pages.summary: Use this page to upload a spreadsheet of Questions or Answers to quickly change the text and settings for many records at once.
pages.content:
Introduction

Use this page to upload a spreadsheet of Questions or Answers to quickly change the text and settings for many records at once.

Questions

The Question section has two parts:

  • Download a spreadsheet of all the questions
  • Upload a spreadsheet of questions to update settings in the data portal

Download Questions Template

The question spreadsheet contains a list of all question text that you can then use to quickly edit the text and then upload back into the data portal.

The spreadsheet contains the following columns:

  • Question Code - The unique code of a question.
  • Question (en) - The English question text.
  • Question (ka) - The Georgian question text.
  • Exclude Question from Analysis - Whether or not the question should be excluded from being analyzed on the explore data page.

Question (xx) Columns

The specific Question (xx) columns that appear in the spreadsheet depend on the Language of Dataset field in the Settings Form page. If you have only one language selected, then there will only be one Question (xx) column in the spreadsheet. If you have three languages selected, then there will be three Question (xx) columns in the spreadsheet.

If you are using this spreadsheet to create translations of the question text, and if you have not already done so, before downloading the spreadsheet you must select all of the languages you want the dataset to have in the Language of Dataset field in the Settings Form page.

Exclude Question from Analysis Column

The Exclude Question from Analysis column indicates if the question should not be allowed to be analyzed in the explore data page. Types of questions that you may want to exclude are interviewer ID, household ID, weights, and any other questions that you feel the public should not have access to analyze.

Filling out the Spreadsheet

The text in the Question Code column should not be changed. When you upload the spreadsheet, the code is used to find the existing question in the data portal and update it settings accordingly. If you change the code, the question will not be able to be found.

You can update the text in all of the Question (xx) columns. For instance, if you need to fix the question text so it is more user friendly or if you want to enter a translation of the question text.

If you want to exclude a question from analysis, enter a Y in the Exclude Question from Analysis column. If you do not want to exclude the question, leave the value blank.

Upload Question Spreadsheet

Once you are done updating the spreadsheet, you can use this section to upload the spreadsheet to load all of the changes into the data portal.

Answers

The Answers section has two parts:

  • Download a spreadsheet of all the answers
  • Upload a spreadsheet of answers to update settings in the data portal

Download Answers Template

The answer spreadsheet contains a list of all questions and their answers that you can then use to quickly edit the text and then upload back into the data portal.

The spreadsheet contains the following columns:

  • Question Code - The unique code of a question.
  • Value - The unique value for a question answer.
  • Sort Order - The sort order for the question answer.
  • Answer (en) - The English answer text.
  • Answer (ka) - The Georgian answer text.
  • Exclude Answer from Analysis - Whether or not the answer should be excluded from being analyzed on the explore data page.
  • Can Exclude During Analysis -  Whether or not a person has the ability to excluded the answer during an analysis on the explore data page.

Answer (xx) Columns

The specific Answer (xx) columns that appear in the spreadsheet depend on the Language of Dataset field in the Settings Form page. If you have only one language selected, then there will only be one Answer (xx) column in the spreadsheet. If you have three languages selected, then there will be three Answer (xx) columns in the spreadsheet.

If you are using this spreadsheet to create translations of the answer text and if you have not already done so, before downloading the spreadsheet you must select all of the languages you want the dataset to have in the Language of Dataset field in the Settings Form page.

Exclude Answer from Analysis Column

The Exclude Answer from Analysis column indicates if the answer should never be included in the analysis in the explore data page. Types of answer that you may want to exclude are interviewer ID, household ID, weights, and any other answers that you feel the public should not have access to analyze.

Can Exclude During Analysis Column

The Can Exclude During Analysis column indicates if a person has the ability to choose whether or not to exclude the answer during an analysis. Types of answers that you may want to exclude are does not apply and refuse to answer.

Filling out the Spreadsheet

The text in the Question Code and Value columns should not be changed. When you upload the spreadsheet, the code is used to find the existing question and the value is used to find the existing question answer in the data portal and then update the answer settings accordingly. If you change the code or value, the question and answer will not be able to be found.

You can update the text in all of the Answer (xx) columns. For instance, if you need to fix the answer text so it is more user friendly or if you want to enter a translation of the answer text.

If you want to exclude an answer from analysis, enter a Y in the Exclude Answer from Analysis column. If you do not want to exclude the answer, leave the value blank.

If you want a person to be able to choose to exclude an answer from analysis, enter a Y in the Can Exclude During Analysis column. If you do not want to exclude the answer, leave the value blank.

Upload Answer Spreadsheet

Once you are done updating the spreadsheet, you can use this section to upload the spreadsheet to load all of the changes into the data portal.

Next Steps

pages.title: Question Data Type Mass Changes
pages.summary: Use this page to indicate the data type of each question. A question that does not have a data type selected cannot be analyzed. If a question does not have pre-defined answers it cannot be selected as Categorical.
pages.content:
Use this page to indicate the data type of each question. A question that does not have a data type selected cannot be analyzed. If a question does not have pre-defined answers it cannot be selected as Categorical.

For numerical questions, a histogram chart will be used during analysis. You can set the histogram bar size and the min and max value of the chart.

sections.title: Group Questions
sections.summary: Use this section to put similar questions together in a group. You can also create a subgroup of questions.

pages.title: Listing Page
pages.summary: This section allows you to put similar questions together in a group. You can also create a subgroup of questions.
pages.content:
Introduction

This section allows you to put similar questions together in a group. You can also create a subgroup of questions.

Groups have a name and description. The description is optional and you can use it to give context to the set of questions in the group.

Groups will be visible in the codebook and on the explore page. There is a setting to indicate if you want the group description to be shown in the chart titles.

By default, groups are put at the top of the codebook and all ungrouped questions will appear after the groups. You can use the Sorting page to further control the order of the groups and questions.

Column Explanations

  • Name - The name of the group.
  • Subgroup - The name of the subgroup, if the record is a subgroup.
  • Description - A brief explanation of the group.
  • Include the Description in the Chart Titles - Whether or the group description should be included in the chart titles.
  • Questions in this Group - Indicates how many questions are in this group. Click on the button to view the questions.
  • Actions - This is where you will find the buttons to edit and delete a record.

Row Order

The rows are sorted according to the group order defined in the Sorting page.

You can click on any of the column headers to change the sort order of the rows.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • New - click to create a new Group record.

Table Columns

  • Questions in this Group column - click to view a popup that lists all questions in the group like the following:

  • Blue pencil icon in the Actions column - click to edit the Group record
  • Red X icon in the Actions column - click to delete the Group record,

pages.title: Form Page
pages.summary: Add/Edit a Group record.
pages.content:
Introduction

Add/Edit a Group record.

Assigning Questions to the Group

At the bottom of the form is a section for adding questions to the group. The list of questions is limited to those that are already assigned to the group and to those questions that have not been assigned to any group yet.

You can either browse through the list of questions or you can filter by question code or question text by entering text into the textboxes under the table headers.

To add a question to the group, select the checkbox in the first column.

To remove a question from the group, deselect the checkbox in the first column.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • View All - click to go back to the listing of Group records

  • Dataset Options - click to view all of the options to manage the Dataset
  • All Datasets - click to go back to the listing of Dataset records

Form Buttons

  • Update Group - click to save the Group record
  • Reset - click to reset the form fields. If this is a new record all form fields will be empty. If you are editing an existing record, the form fields will be reset to the values they had when the page loaded.
  • Cancel - click to ignore any changes and go back to the Listing Page

Before Getting Started

There is a Form guide book that you should review so that you understand error messages, where to find form field hints, how to enter translations, etc.

sections.title: Sort Groups/Questions
sections.summary: Use this section to sort all groups and questions into the order that you desire.

pages.title: Listing Page
pages.summary: This page allows you to sort all groups and questions into the order that you desire.
pages.content:
Introduction

This page allows you to sort all groups and questions into the order that you desire.

By default, the question sort order is set to be the same as the order of the questions in the data file.

When groups are added, the group sort order is initially set so the groups appear at the top of the list.

If the dataset has groups, you can view and sort the items in a group by clicking on the 'View Items in this Group' button in the last column in the table. This will reload the page and show all of the groups and questions in that group so that you can sort them.

Navigating Groups

When the page first loads, you are seeing all groups and questions that are at the main level. The header for this is as follows:

If the dataset has groups and you click on the group's 'View Items in this Group' button, the page will reload showing all sub-groups and questions in that group. The header for sub-groups looks like the following:

Note that the 'Main Items' is now a link. If you click on this you will go back to the main level of groups and questions.

Sorting

There are two ways to sort items:

  • Drag and drop
  • Select the item(s) to move and then indicate where to move them

Drag and Drop

You can drag and drop items to re-arrange the sort order. When you move an item, the item is highlighted yellow as seen below.

When you are done dragging the item and drop it in the place you want it to be, the color will remain yellow as seen below. After a couple seconds the yellow highlight color will fade away.

You must click on the green 'Save Settings' button to save any changes you make.

Select Items

If you want to move several items at once, there is another way to move them. First, select the items you want to move as seen below.

The items that you select will turn yellow. Now, just above the table is a drop down field as seen below.

Open the drop-down and select where you want to move the selected items as seen below.

After you select where to move the items, the selected item will turn blue as seen below.

If this is what you want, click on the blue Go button that is to the right of drop-down. The items will now be re-sorted with the highlight colors still showing as seen below. After a couple seconds the yellow and blue highlight colors will fade away.

You must click on the green 'Save Settings' button to save any changes you make.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • Dataset Options - click to view all of the options to manage the Dataset
  • All Datasets - click to go back to the listing of Dataset records

Form Buttons

  • Save Settings - click to save the sort order for the items on the page

sections.title: Weight Data
sections.summary: Use this section to establish weights and assign questions to the weights.

pages.title: Listing Page
pages.summary: This section allows you to identify which question(s) contain a weight value and which questions that weight should be applied to.
pages.content:
Introduction

This section allows you to identify which question(s) contain a weight value and which questions that weight should be applied to.

A dataset can have multiple weights, but one must be selected as the default weight. A default weight is automatically applied to all questions. For weights that are not the default weight, you can choose to apply the weight to all of the questions or only specific questions.

During analysis, if two questions are being compared and they are of different weights, the default weight is used for both.

Column Explanations

  • Weight Name - The name of the weight.
  • Question with Weight - The question in the dataset that contains the weight values.
  • Is Default Weight - Whether or not this weight is applied to all questions during analysis by default if no weight is indicated.
  • Applies To - Whether the weight applies to all questions or a subset of questions.
  • Actions - This is where you will find the buttons to edit and delete a record.

Row Order

The rows are sorted according to the order they were entered into the data portal.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • New - click to create a new Weight record.

Table Columns

  • Button in Applies To column - if the weight does not apply to all questions, a button will be present that when clicked will open a popup showing all questions that the weight applies to, like the following:

  • Blue pencil icon in the Actions column - click to edit the Weight record
  • Red X icon in the Actions column - click to delete the Weight record,

pages.title: Form Page
pages.summary: Add/Edit a Weight record.
pages.content:
Introduction

Add/Edit a Weight record.

Use the Question with Weight field to indicate which question in the dataset has the weight values.

The Default Weight field is used to indicate if this weight should be used by default during analysis if the user does not select a weight.

If this weight is not the default weight, you will then be asked whether or not this weight should be applied to all questions.

If the weight does not apply to all questions, you will then be shown a table of all questions. This table contains checkboxes that you should use to select all of the questions that can be used with this weight.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • View All - click to go back to the listing of Group records

  • Dataset Options - click to view all of the options to manage the Dataset
  • All Datasets - click to go back to the listing of Dataset records

Form Buttons

  • Update Weight - click to save the Weight record
  • Reset - click to reset the form fields. If this is a new record all form fields will be empty. If you are editing an existing record, the form fields will be reset to the values they had when the page loaded.
  • Cancel - click to ignore any changes and go back to the Listing Page

sections.title: Make Mappable
sections.summary: Use this section to indicate which questions are geographic in nature so that the analysis screen can include a map.

pages.title: Listing Page
pages.summary: Use this page to indicate which questions are geographic in nature so that the analysis screen can include a map.
pages.content:
Introduction

Use this page to indicate which questions are geographic in nature so that the analysis screen can include a map.

Column Explanations

  • Question - The name of the question that is geographic in nature.
  • Shapeset - The name of the shapeset that has been assigned to this question.
  • Max Range of Choropleth Map is Adjustable - Whether the range of the choropleth scale is from 0 to 100% (a value of No) or whether the range of the choropleth scale is determined by the max data values.
  • Actions - This is where you will find the buttons to edit and delete a record.

Row Order

The rows are sorted according to the order they were entered into the data portal.

pages.title: Form Page
pages.summary: Add/Edit a Mappable Question record.
pages.content:
Introduction

Add/Edit a Mappable Question record.

Selecting the Question and Map

The first thing you need to do is select a geographic question (i.e., region, district, etc) and then select the correct map that matches the question. There can be small variations of the same map so read the map names carefully.

Matching Question Answers to Map Shapes

After you select the question and map, a table will be created with two columns. The left column is the list of possible answers for the question. The right column is where you need to select the corresponding map shape for each possible question answers.

After making the question and map selection, the data portal will automatically try to find matches. When it does, the map shapes will be pre-selected. When it does not, the map shape selector will have a red highlight around it to try and make it obvious that these fields need attention. When you make a selection, the red highlight will disappear.

Adjustable Map Scale

The last form field asks if you want the map color scale to be fixed or if you want it to be adjusted to match the question response range. By default, with a value of No, the map scale goes from 0 - 100%. For some cases this may be fine. But if the question data results in each map shape having similar values, the differences might not be visually noticeable. For instance, look at the map below which is not using an adjustable scale.

If you look at the percent values on the map, you will see that percents range from about 3% to about 30%. Since this data is relatively close together, the color difference between 3% and 30% is barely noticeable when the map color scale range goes from 0-100%.

If you update the setting so the adjustable map scale is set to Yes, the map will now look like the following:

Since the scale is only between 0% and 30%, the color difference between 3% and 30% is much easier to see.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • View All - click to go back to the listing of Group records

  • Dataset Options - click to view all of the options to manage the Dataset
  • All Datasets - click to go back to the listing of Dataset records

Form Buttons

  • Update Mappable Question - click to save the Mappable Question record
  • Reset - click to reset the form fields. If this is a new record all form fields will be empty. If you are editing an existing record, the form fields will be reset to the values they had when the page loaded.
  • Cancel - click to ignore any changes and go back to the Listing Page

Introduction

  • Issues with Data - Indicates if there are any issues with the dataset data.
  • Data Added to Site - The date the dataset was uploaded to the site.

pages.title: Settings (Form Page)
pages.summary: Add/Edit a Dataset record.
pages.content:
Introduction

Add/Edit a Dataset record.

Editing Dataset Limitations

At this time, it is not possible to edit an existing Dataset record and load a new data file. The reason for this is that there are so many options for managing the dataset (i.e., multiple languages, question text, answer text, question data types, etc) and the process of determining which options should stay or be removed is not trivial.

If you have to update the data file, you will have to create a new Dataset record and start over. If you have already set a lot of options for the original dataset record, it is suggested that you do not delete the original dataset record until after you have copied all settings that are needed.

  • Reset - click to reset the form fields. If this is a new record all form fields will be empty. If you are editing an existing record, the form fields will be reset to the values they had when the page loaded.
  • Cancel - click to ignore any changes and go back to the Listing Page

Codebook

On the public dataset dashboard page, the codebook only shows:

  • categorical questions that have predefined answers
  • numerical questions that have the histogram settings filled in
  • questions and answers that have been marked for public viewing

When viewing the dataset dashboard under the Dataset Management section, all questions and answers will appear in the codebook. A lock icon will appear next to the question text for questions that are not available to the public, like the following:

pages.summary: Run analyses on the dataset data and get the results in chart and table formats.
pages.content:
Introduction

Run analyses on the dataset data and get the results in chart and table formats.

Differences

The Explore Data page is the exact same as the Explore Dataset Data page that is available to the public, but with a few differences. Please refer to the Explore Dataset Data guide for full details about how to explore the data and then see below for the differences.

List of Questions

On the public explore dataset data page, only questions that have been marked for public viewing are shown in the list of questions. Under the Dataset Management section, all questions are shown in the list of questions. A lock icon is shown to indicate which questions are private.

Please note that just because a question is in the list does not mean it should be selected for analysis. For instance, analyzing the Household ID will not really return any valuable information.

Highlights

In order to create highlights of an analysis in a dataset, you must use the explore dataset data page under the Dataset Management section, not the explore dataset data page that is available to the public.

To save an analysis as a highlight, click on the yellow star icon in the top-left corner of the chart.

You can learn more about managing highlights in the Highlights guide.

pages.title: Download Data
pages.summary: Download the entire dataset in any format you desire.
pages.content:
Introduction

You can use this page to download the entire dataset in several possible formats such as CSV, R, SPSS, and STATA. You also have the ability to download the original dataset file that was upload to the site. The difference between these two options is that the original option is the exact file that was uploaded, while the format options will have data, text, settings, etc that were set in the option pages for the dataset.

This download is different than what is on the dashboard page in that this download includes all records and questions from the dataset, whereas the download from the dashboard page only includes the data that you have indicated can be downloaded by the public.

pages.title: Highlights
pages.summary: Highlights are visuals (charts and maps) that highlight interesting aspects of your dataset and are shown on the dashboard page and the data portal home page.
pages.content:
Introduction

Highlights are visuals (charts and maps) that highlight interesting aspects of your dataset and are shown on the dashboard page and the data portal home page.

This page shows you the highlights that have been created for your dataset. You can edit the highlight description, make the highlight always show on the data portal home page, or delete the highlight.

Create A Highlight

You cannot create a highlight on this page. To create a highlight:

  • go to the dataset explore data page
  • create the analysis you want for the highlight
  • click on the yellow star icon in the top-left corner of the visual analysis

Highlights On Data Portal Home Page

Two highlights will always appear at the bottom of the data portal home page. One highlight is randomly selected from all highlights in the data portal. The other highlight that will always show is the one that is marked as 'Permanently Show on Home Page'. You can mark a highlight as permanent by clicking on the black pushpin icon in Actions column.

Column Explanations

  • Questions - This will be a list of all questions that are included in the highlight analysis. There is a label above each question to indicate how the question is being used in the analysis:
    • Question - Indicates the main question being analyzed. There will always be a question label. 
    • Broken Down By - Indicates the question that is being compared to the Question. This is optional.
    • Filtered By - Indicates the question that is being used to filter the analysis. This is optional.
  • Permanently Show on Home Page - Whether this highlight is set to always show on the data portal home page.
  • Description - The description of the highlight, if it exists.
  • Actions - This is where you will find the buttons to edit the description, make the highlight always show on the data portal home page, or delete the record.

Row Order

The rows are sorted in the order they were created, with oldest on top.

You can click on any of the column headers to change the sort order of the rows.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • Dataset Options - click to view all of the options to manage the Dataset
  • All Datasets - click to go back to the listing of Dataset records

Table Columns

  • View button in first column - click to view the highlight in a new window
  • Black pushpin icon in the Actions column - click to make the Highlight always show on the data portal home page
  • Blue pencil icon in the Actions column - click to edit the Highlight description
  • Red X icon in the Actions column - click to delete the Highlight record.

pages.title: Warnings
pages.summary: Due to the structure of statistical files (i.e., SPSS, STATA, etc), the data portal can analyze the question settings and the data and see if there are any issues. If there are, this page will tell you what they are.
pages.content:
Introduction

Due to the structure of statistical files (i.e., SPSS, STATA, etc), the data portal can analyze the question settings and the data and see if there are any issues. If there are, this page will tell you what they are.

The Warnings page looks at the following three issues:

  • Questions with no text
  • Questions with no answers
  • Questions with bad answers

It is possible to fix the warnings through the data portal, but in some cases it may be better to make the fixes in the original data file and then upload the new file to the data portal.

Questions with no text

Sometimes a question in the statistical file is created by adding a code value, but no text value. For instance a code of 'A1' was entered, but no text explaining what 'A1' represents was provided. These questions with no text will be listed in this section.

Questions that are missing text will not be available for analysis. You can add the missing question text by clicking on the 'Add Question Text' button.

Questions with no answers

In a statistical file, it is possible to define the list of possible answers for a categorical question. This section lists all questions that do not have a list of possible answers.

Categorical Questions

Categorical questions that are missing answers will not be available for analysis. You can add the missing answers by clicking on the 'Add Answers' button.

If a question that is supposed to be categorical is marked as numerical, then you need to go to the Question Data Type page to change the question type to categorical. After that, you should check back on this page to see if the question has been removed from the list. If the question is still in the list, then you need to add the missing answers by clicking on the 'Add Answers' button.

Numerical Questions

If a question is marked as numerical, than a list of possible answers does not exist and the question will be available for analysis.

Questions with bad answers

In a statistical file, it is possible to define the list of possible answers for a categorical question. This section lists all categorical questions that have data values that are not in the list of possible answers. 

It is possible that the error occurred during entering the data into the data file. If this is the case, you will need to update your data file and then upload the new file to the data portal.

It is also possible that when entering the list of possible answers, a value was missed. If this is the case you have two options:

  • Update the data file and then upload the new file into the data portal
  • Click on the blue pencil icon to edit the list of possible answers in the data portal

pages.summary: This section allows you to put similar questions together in a group. You can also create a subgroup of questions.
pages.content:
This section allows you to put similar questions together in a group. You can also create a subgroup of questions.

Groups have a name and description. You can use the description to give context to the set of questions in the group.

Groups will be visible in the codebook and on the explore page. It is up to you on whether or not the group description is included in the chart titles.

By default, groups are put at the top of the codebook and all ungrouped questions will appear after the groups. You can use the %{link} to further control the order of the groups and questions.

pages.content:
This page allows you to sort all groups and questions into the order that you desire.

By defualt, the question sort order is set to be the same as the order of the questions in the data file.

When groups are added, the group sort order is initially set so the groups appear at the top of the list.

If you have created groups, you can view and sort the items in that group by clicking on the button in the last column in the table.

pages.title: Listing Page
pages.summary: This section allows you to identify which question(s) contain a weight value and which questions that weight should be applied to.
pages.content:
This section allows you to identify which question(s) contain a weight value and which questions that weight should be applied to.

A time series can have multiple weights, but one must be selected as the default weight. A default weight is automatically applied to all questions. For weights that are not the default weight, you can choose to apply the weight to all of the questions or only specific questions.

During analysis, if two questions are being compared and they are of different weights, the default weight is used for both.

pages.summary: Guide Books is where you can manage the information and hierarchy of the books that Guides can be assigned to. On this page, you can see a list of all the Guide Books that are in the data portal.
pages.content:
Introduction

Guide Books is where you can manage the information and hierarchy of the books that Guides can be assigned to.These Guide Books are available to users in the Support section.

On this page, you can see a list of all the Guide Books that are in the data portal.

Column Explanations

  • Title - The name of the guide book.
    • Guide Books that are a part of another Guide Book will have the title indented to help show you the overall Guide Book hierarchy.
  • Summary - A brief summary of the guide book.
  • Guide Book URL - The URL to the guide book in the Support section (i.e., /en/support/manage_datasets)
  • Make Available to the Public - Whether or not the guide book should be shown in the Support section.
  • Only Admins can view this Guide Book - Whether not not the guide book is visible to the world or just Admins in the Support section.
  • Actions - This is where you will find the buttons to edit and delete a record.

Row Order

The rows are sorted in the order indicated by the Sort Order field and is the same order the Guide Books will appear in the Support section.

If a Guide Book has a collection of Guide Books assigned to it, then all of those children Guide Books will be ordered by the Sort Order field within the parent Guide Book.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • New - click to create a new Guide Book record. 
  • Admin Section - click to go back to the page that lists all of the sections in the Admin Section

Table Columns

  • Blue pencil icon in the Actions column - click to edit the Guide Book record
  • Red X icon in the Actions column - click to delete the Guide Book record, 

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the Guide Book guide book:

  • Form Page

The Parent Guide Book field is used to indicate if the Guide Book is part of another Guide Book (i.e., the Edit Text on Site belongs to the Admin Section guide book). If the Guide book has no parent, then leave this field blank. If the field already has a value click on the 'x' icon to remove the selection.

Show Guide Link in Sub-Navbar field

The Show Guide Link in Sub-Navbar field is used to indicate where on the data portal page the Guide summary and link to the Guide page should be shown. A value of 'No' means that the Guide summary will appear at the top of the page like the following:

A value of 'Yes' means that instead of showing the Guide summary at the top of the page, just a link to the Guide page will appear on the right side of the sub-navbar (i.e., the blue Support link). The sub-navbar appears just below the main navbar and is only used on the following pages:

  • Dataset dashboard page
  • Dataset explore page
  • Time series dashboard page

Page Assignments Section

The Page Assignments section is where you indicate which data portal pages will show a link to this guide. You can assign a guide to one or more pages. To add more assignments, click on the green 'Add Page Assignment' button. To delete an existing assignment record, click on the red X icon on the right side of the record row.

This section is only editable to people with the Admin role. If you are not an Admin, this section will be locked like the following:

sections.title: API Documentation
sections.summary: Use this section to manage the API documentation.

pages.title: API Version Listing Page
pages.summary: API Version is where you can manage the API documentation. On this page, you can see a list of all the API Version and API Method records in the data portal.
pages.content:
Introduction

API Version is where you can manage the API documentation. On this page, you can see a list of all the API Version and API Method records in the data portal.

API

The data portal has an API (application programming interface) which means any developer can create an app that can programmatically access the data in the portal data and use it for their own purpose. For example, think of all of the weather apps that are out there. There are only a few services that actually track the weather and these apps use an API to get the weather and then show it in some unique way that their users will like.

The data portal API offers the following access to the data:

  • Dataset Catalog - get a list of all the datasets
  • Dataset Details - get the details for a dataset (i.e., name, methodology, dates, reports, etc)
  • Dataset Codebook - get the codebook for a dataset (i.e, a list of questions and possible answers)
  • Dataset Analysis - run an analysis for a question in a dataset
  • Time Series Catalog - get a list of all the time series
  • Time Series Details - get the details for a time series (i.e, name, datasets, dates, etc)
  • Time Series Codebook - get the codebook for a time series (i.e., a list of questions and possible answers)
  • Time Series Analysis - run an analysis for a question in a time series

API Method

An API Method allows a person to get specific information from the data portal. Each of the items listed above are API Methods (i.e., catalog of datasets, dataset details, dataset analysis, etc). The API Method documentation indicates the following:

  • the URL to access the method
  • a list of required parameters, if any
  • a list of optional parameters, if any
  • what is returned when the method is called
  • examples of calling the method with parameters and what information is returned

API Version

An API Version is a collection of API Methods. When a major change occurs to the data portal features, a new API version should be created with a new set of API methods that can use the new major change.

Column Explanations

  • Title - This is the title of the text. This title may ore may not be shown in the data portal.
  • Permalink - The URL to the API Version in the API section (i.e., /en/api/v1)
  • Make Available to the Public - Whether or not the API Version should be released to the world.
  • Methods - A list of all the methods in this version
  • Actions - This is where you will find the buttons to edit and delete a record.

Row Order

The rows are sorted by the Title.

In each row, the Method column has a listing of all API Methods in the API Version. The API Methods are sorted in the order indicated by the API Method Sort Order field and is the same order the API Methods will appear on the API page.

Page Actions

Below is a list of links and buttons that you can click on this page.

Gray Bar

  • New - click to create a new API Version record. 
  • Admin Section - click to go back to the page that lists all of the sections in the Admin Section

Table Columns

  • New button in the Method column - click to add a API Method record to the API Version
  • Link in Method column - click to view the API Method record
  • Blue pencil icon in the Actions column - click to edit the API Version record
  • Red X icon in the Actions column - click to delete the API Version record

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the API Documentation guide book:

  • API Version Form Page
  • API Method View Page
  • API Method Form Page

GeoJSON File field

GeoJSON is a standard for representing simple geographical features like points, lines, and polygons. These features can then be loaded on top of an interactive map to highlight shape boundaries like regions and districts.

Typically, boundaries are maintained in a GIS application like QGIS. These GIS applications can then be used to export a GeoJSON file that can be loaded here.

pages.title: Admin Home
pages.summary: This is where you can access all of the admin sections to manage users, categories, site text, and the guide text along with download spreadsheets on who has been using the site.
pages.content:
Introduction

This is where you can access all of the admin sections to manage users, categories, site text, and the guide text. There is also the ability to download two spreadsheets that indicate which datasets have been downloaded and which API methods have been used.

Spreadsheet Download

The data portal keeps track whom is downloading dataset files and whom is accessing the API. A person must create an account before being allowed to download a dataset or access the API so the data portal knows whom is making each request.

This section of the page allows you to download this information in a spreadsheet format.

Download Dataset

This spreadsheet will tell you whom has downloaded a dataset, which dataset it was, what file format (i.e., CSV, SPSS, etc) was requested, and when the request was made.

Below is a list of the columns in the spreadsheet and a brief explanation of each column:

  • Date - the date and time the dataset was downloaded
  • First Name - first name of the user
  • Last Name - last name of the user
  • Age Group - age of the user
  • Country of Residence - country of the user
  • Email Address - email of the user
  • Affiliation - where the user works
  • Status - the type of organization the user works for
  • Short description of research objective
  • Dataset - the name of the dataset downloaded
  • File Type - the file type requested (i.e., CSV, STATA, SPSS, etc)
  • Language - the language of the dataset (i.e., English or Georgian)
  • Download Type - if the download was made from the public pages or from the admin section

API Call

This spreadsheet will tell you whom has made a call to the API, which API method was called, which dataset or time series was requested, what analysis parameters were provided, and when the request was made.

Below is a list of the columns in the spreadsheet and a brief explanation of each column:

  • Date - the date and time the API call was made
  • API Key ID - the API Key of a user that was used to access the API
  • User ID - ID of the user making the request
  • Name - name of the user making the request
  • Dataset ID - ID of the dataset being requested
  • Dataset - Name of the dataset being requested
  • Time Series ID - ID of the time series being requested
  • Time Series - Name of the time series being requested
  • IP Address - IP address of the user
  • API Locale - which language was requested (i.e., English or Georgian)
  • API Version - which version of the API was requested (i.e., v1, v2, v3, etc)
  • API Action - which API method was called (i.e., dataset, dataset_analysis, dataset_codebook, etc)
  • Question Code - the code of the question being analyzed
  • Broken Down By Code - the code of the question being used to make a comparison analysis
  • Filtered By Code - the code of the question used to filter the analysis
  • Can Exclude - whether or not can exclude answers were included in the analysis
  • With Title - whether the title was included in the analysis results
  • With Chart Data - whether the data formatted for charts was included in the analysis results
  • With Map Data - whether the data formatted for maps was included in the analysis results
  • Browser - which browser the user used
  • Browser Version - the version of the browser
  • OS - which operating system the user used
  • OS Platform - generic name of the operating system
  • App - browser details
  • Is Mobile Device? - was the request made on a mobile device

Next Steps

Below are links to the guide book of each item in the Admin Section:

  • Edit Text on Site
  • Categories
  • Guide Books
  • Guides
  • API Documentation
  • Shapesets
  • Users

sections.title: Dataset Exploration
sections.summary: Learn how to search for a dataset, review dataset meta data, explore the dataset data, share a dataset analysis result, and download the dataset.

pages.title: Dataset Search
pages.summary: Browse and search through all of the datasets on the data portal.
pages.content:
Introduction

Run analyses on the dataset data and get the results in chart and table formats.

Page Layout

Top Bar

The top bar contains the ability to search, sort and filter the datasets by categories.

Search

The following dataset fields are included in the search:

  • Title
  • Summary
  • Methodology

Please note that the question and answer text are not included in the search.

When you run a search, the search query that you entered will be highlighted in each dataset item, like the following:

Sort

By default the datasets are ordered so that the most recently released dataset is first. You can choose from one of the following sort options:

  • Title - sort all datasets by the titles
  • Date Released - sort all datasets by the date that they were released to the public
  • Relevance - sort all datasets by the relevance of the search results - only works if you have entered a search query

Category Filter

In the far-right side of the top bar is a link with the text 'Choose Category'. If you click on this, all categories will appear, like the following:

You can click on any category to filter the datasets to only those assigned to that category.

You can close the category list by clicking on the 'Choose Category' link again.

Dataset Items

Each dataset item will show the following information:

  • Dataset title - click on this to go to the Dataset Dashboard page
  • Dates the survey data was collected
  • Date the survey data was released to the public
  • Summary of the dataset
  • Link to Time Series Dashboard page if this dataset is part of a Time Series
  • Blue down arrow icon - click on this to get a list of formats the dataset can be downloaded in, like the following:

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the Dataset Exploration guide book:

  • Dataset Dashboard Page
  • Explore Dataset Data Page

pages.title: Dataset Dashboard
pages.summary: The Dashboard shows you information about a dataset like methodology, highlights, codebook, reports, metadata, etc.
pages.content:
Introduction

The Dashboard shows you information about a dataset like methodology, highlights, codebook, reports, metadata, etc.

Sections

The Dashboard can be broken up into three sections, each of which is described below.

Top-Left: Intro

The dataset introduction contains the following information:

  • Title of the dataset
  • Dates the dataset data was collected
  • Date the dataset data was released to the public
  • Summary of the dataset

Top-Right: Buttons

The top-right corner of the dashboard contains links/buttons for the following:

  • Categories - If the dataset is assigned to categories (i.e., Education, Social Protection, etc), then these categories will appear at the top. Clicking on these categories will take you to the Dataset Search page and will show all datasets that are assigned to the category you selected.
  • Explore Data - Click on this link to go to the dataset explore page that allows you to run analyses of the dataset data.
  • Time Series - If the dataset belongs to a time series analysis, then a link to view the Time Series Dashboard page will be shown.

Bottom: Detailed Information

Highlights

The highlights section shows you interesting findings from the dataset data. If you click on the chart title, you will be taken to the explore dataset data page and the highlight analysis will be shown. You also have the option to download the chart as an image or PDF file by clicking on the blue down arrow icon in the top-right corner of the chart.

Methodology

The methodology section explains how the dataset data was gathered.

Codebook

The codebook section shows you a list of all questions in the dataset. Each question will indicate the following:

  • question text
  • question code
  • data type (i.e., categorical or numerical)
  • for categorical questions - a list of possible answers for the question
  • for numerical questions - a list of descriptive statistics (i.e., mean, mode, variance, etc.)

You can use the search box at the top of the section to search through all question and answer text.

If you click on the question text, you will be taken to the explore dataset data page where an analysis of the selected question will be shown.

You can download a text file of the codebook by clicking on the blue down arrow icon in the top-right corner of the codebook section.

Reports

The reports section shows a list of reports that have been written about the dataset. Each report will have the following information:

  • Title of the report
  • Date the report was released to the public
  • Summary of the report
  • Language the report was written in

You can download the report by clicking on the blue down arrow icon in the top-right corner of the report row.

Metadata

The metadata section shows the following information about the dataset:

  • Categories - list of all categories that the dataset is assigned to
  • Dates Collected - dates the dataset data was collected
  • Date Released - date the dataset data was released to the public
  • Total Responses - the number of responses in the dataset
  • Analyzable Questions - how many questions can be analyzed in the data portal
  • Weighted Data - If the dataset data is weighted, it means that the dataset results can be applied to the general population
  • Date Added to Site - date the dataset was first published on the data portal
  • Date Last Updated - date the dataset was last updated in the data portal

Legal

The legal section contains text explaining how you can use UNICEF's data.

Download Data

The download data section allows you to download the dataset data in the following formats:

  • CSV (spreadsheet)
  • R
  • SPSS
  • STATA

Each download will contain the data file along with a text file of the codebook

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the Dataset Exploration guide book:

  • Dataset Search Page
  • Explore Dataset Data Page

pages.title: Explore Dataset Data
pages.summary: Run analyses on the dataset data and get the results in chart and table formats.
pages.content:
Introduction

Run analyses on the dataset data and get the results in chart and table formats.

Page Layout

Left Side

The left side of the page is where you build your analysis query. Once you have built your query, click on the blue Generate button to run the analysis.

Right Side

The right side of the page is where the results of the analysis will be shown. Once you run an analysis, several tabs will appear.

Chart

The Chart tab will contain a chart showing the results of the analysis.

Table

The Table tab will show the same data as the Chart tab, but in a table format.

Details

The Details tab lists information from the dataset codebook for each option in the analysis query (i.e., question text, question code, data type, list of possible answers, etc).

Download Data

The Download Data tab is where you can download the entire dataset in one of 4 possible formats: CSV, R, SPSS, or STATA,

Selecting a Question to Analyze

To select a question, simply click on the drop down list and find the question you want.

One way to find a question is to scroll down the list and look for the question you want to analyze. However, it is possible that the list of questions can be extremely long (i.e., over 500 questions), so if you know the question text use the search box at the top of the question list to quickly find what you want.

The meaning of the icons on the right side of the list will be explained in the following sections.

Categorical and Numerical Data Types

Each question is either categorical or numerical:

  • Categorical - The question has a predefined list of possible answers (i.e., Region, Urban / Rural, Education Level, etc) and is indicated with the following icon:

  • Numerical - The question is numerical and has no predefined list of possible answers (i.e., Age, Weight, Salary, etc) and is indicated with the following icon:

Analysis Types

Single

A single analysis means that you want to view the responses for a question. This is accomplished by selecting a question under 'Explore Answers To' and not selecting a question from 'Broken Down By'.

Categorical Questions

A single analysis of a categorical question will return a bar chart indicating what percent of the respondents selected each possible answer. In the top-left corner of the chart, you have the ability to switch between a bar chart and a pie chart. This option is only available for this single categorical question analysis.

Numerical Questions

A single analysis of a numerical question will return a histogram showing the breakdown of all responses grouped into particular ranges.

Comparative

A comparative analysis means that you want to compare the responses from two questions. This is accomplished by selecting a question under 'Explore Answers To' and also selecting a question from 'Broken Down By'.

Please note that you can only compare questions that are of the same type, meaning that you can compare categorical questions to each other and numerical questions to each other, but you cannot compare a categorical question to a numerical question.

Categorical Questions

A comparative analysis of categorical questions will return a stacked bar chart indicating what percent of the respondents selected an answer from each question.

Numerical Questions

A comparative analysis of numerical questions will return a scatter plot chart indicating how many respondents selected an answer from each question. Light colored circles indicate few people responded with those particular answers while dark circles indicate many people responded with those particular answers.

Comparative - Filtered

A comparative analysis with a filter means that you want to compare the responses from two questions filtered by the answers from a third question. This is accomplished by selecting a question under 'Explore Answers To', selecting a question from 'Broken Down By', and also selecting a question from 'Filtered By'.

Please note that only categorical questions can be used as filters.

A comparative analysis of categorical questions with a filter will return a stacked bar chart for each possible answer in the filter question. The chart indicates what percent of the respondents selected an answer from all three questions. You will have to look at the title of each chart to see which filter answer is being charted. You will have to scroll down the page to see the chart for each filter answer.

Maps

In addition to viewing results in a chart, some results can also be viewed on a map. Questions that have a geographic reference like Region and District may have the following icon to indicate that the results can be viewed on a map:

When you select a mappable question, an additional Map tab will appear after the Chart tab, as seen below. The map is color coded to indicate the response rate from each shape, where a darker color means more people responded in that shape. Hover over a shape to get the shape name and results.

Weights

When surveys are conducted, it is impossible to survey every single person in a desired population and so only a small subset of the population is questioned. However, if the survey participants are selected properly, it is possible to apply the results of the survey to the desired population. The process of converting the survey results to the population is called weighting the data.

If a dataset has weighted data, the weight will automatically be applied during analysis so the results you are viewing is what applies to the desired population. Look at the 'Weighted By' field to determine if a weight is being used in your analysis.

If a weight is used, the sub-titles in the results will use the label 'Total Unweighted Responses' followed by a red *. The red * indicates that there is a footnote and in the bottom-left of the results the footnote will indicate which weight was applied to the analysis, like the following:

If a weight is not applied to the analysis, then the sub-titles in the results will use the label 'Total Responses', like the following:

Exporting the Analysis

You have the ability to export the analysis results in a couple different ways.

In the top-right corner of the chart are the following icons:

  • Red link icon - click on this to get the code to embed the chart
  • Blue down arrow icon - click on this to download the chart as an image or PDF file

Embed

When you click on the red link icon to embed the chart, you will get a popup like the following:

Simple copy the code into your web page to embed the chart. If you wish, you can adjust the width and height of the chart using the form fields on the left side of the embed code.

Page Actions

In the top-left corner of the page is the following:

  • Available Languages - this will be present if the dataset has been published on the data portal in more than one language. Select the language that you want the analysis to be in and the page will reload in that language.
  • Back to Dashboard - click on this link to go back to the Dataset Dashboard page.

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the Dataset Exploration guide book:

  • Dataset Search Page
  • Dataset Dashboard Page

sections.title: Time Series Exploration
sections.summary: Learn how to find a time series (i.e., panel), review time series meta data, explore the time series data, and share a time series analysis result.

pages.title: Finding a Time Series
pages.summary: There are three places in the data portal where you can find a link to the Time Series dashboard page.
pages.content:
Introduction

There are three places in the data portal where you can find a link to the Time Series dashboard page.

  • Homepage - One of the blocks on the homepage is a Time Series block as seen below. Click anywhere on the block to go to the Time Series Dashboard page.

  • Dataset Search Page - If a dataset belongs to a Time Series, than on the dataset search page, the block of dataset information will contain a link to the Time Series as seen below.

  • Dataset Dashboard Page - Similarly to the Dataset Search page, if a dataset belongs to a Time Series, than on the dataset dashboard page, the block of button in the top-right corner will contain a link to the Time Series as seen below.

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the Time Series Exploration guide book:

  • Time Series Dashboard Page
  • Explore Time Series Data Page

pages.title: Time Series Dashboard
pages.summary: The Dashboard shows you information about a time series like the datasets in the time series, highlights, codebook, metadata, etc.
pages.content:
Introduction

The Dashboard shows you information about a time series like the datasets in the time series, highlights, codebook, metadata, etc.

Sections

The Dashboard can be broken up into three sections, each of which is described below.

Top-Left: Intro

The timer series introduction contains the following information:

  • Title of the time series
  • List of each dataset in the time series with the following:
    • Dates the dataset data was collected
    • Date the dataset data was released to the public
  • Summary of the time series

Top-Right: Buttons

The top-right corner of the dashboard contains links/buttons for the following:

  • Categories - If the time series is assigned to categories (i.e., Education, Social Protection, etc), then these categories will appear at the top. Clicking on these categories will take you to the Dataset Search page and will show all datasets that are assigned to the category you selected.
  • Explore Data - Click on this link to go to the time series explore page that allows you to run analyses of the time series data.

Bottom: Detailed Information

Highlights

The highlights section shows you interesting findings from the time series data. If you click on the chart title, you will be taken to the explore time series data page and the highlight analysis will be shown. You also have the option to download the chart as an image or PDF file by clicking on the blue down arrow icon in the top-right corner of the chart.

Codebook

The codebook section shows you a list of all questions in the time series. Each question will indicate the following:

  • question text
  • question code
  • list of possible answers for the question

You can use the search box at the top of the section to search through all question and answer text.

If you click on the question text, you will be taken to the explore time series data page where an analysis of the selected question will be shown.

Datasets

The datasets section shows a list of all the datasets that are in the time series. Each dataset has the following information:

  • Title of the dataset
  • Dates the dataset data was collected
  • Date the dataset data was released to the public
  • Summary of the time series
  • Blue down arrow icon to download the dataset data file

Metadata

The metadata section shows the following information about the time series:

  • Categories - list of all categories that the dataset is assigned to
  • Dates Collected - dates each dataset data was collected
  • Date Released - dates each dataset data was released to the public
  • Date Added to Site - date the time series was first published on the data portal
  • Date Last Updated - date the time series was last updated in the data portal

Legal

The legal section contains text explaining how you can use UNICEF's data.

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the Time Series Exploration guide book:

  • Finding a Time Series
  • Explore Time Series Data Page

sections.title: User Accounts
sections.summary: Learn how to create a user account and edit the settings like email, password, notifications, and API access tokens.

pages.title: Create Account
pages.summary: This guide goes through the process of creating an account and setting your notification preferences.
pages.content:
Introduction

There are three reasons why someone would want to create an account on the data portal site.

  1. Notifications - if you create an account you can sign up to get notified by email whenever a new dataset is published on the data portal.
  2. Download Datasets - in order to be able to download a dataset, the data portal requires the creation of an account so UNICEF can track the analytics on whom is downloading the data.
  3. API - the data portal offers an API that allows developers to programmatically access the data in the portal data, and in order to get access to the API an account is required.

How to Create An Account

In the top-right corner of every page is a link to Sign In or Create Account. Click on the Create Account link to start the process.

Account Form

The first thing you will notice is that there are a lot fields that must be filled out to create an account, and on top of that most of them are required (as indicated by the * after the field label).

The reason why there are so many fields and they are required is that it allows UNICEF to have analytics about the type of people that are getting notifications and/or downloading data.

Notifications

At the bottom of the form is a field for receiving notifications when new datasets are added. Check this form field to indicate that you want to receive notifications. You can then indicate if you want to receive notifications in English or Georgian (ქართული).

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the User Account guide book:

  • User Settings

pages.title: User Settings
pages.summary: This guide goes through how to edit the user settings from when you created the account (i.e., name, email, password, notifications, etc). along with how to create API access tokens.
pages.content:
Introduction

The User Settings page allows you to do two things:

  1. Settings - edit your user settings like name, email, password, notifications, etc
  2. API Access Tokens - create an API access token so you can use the data portal's API

Settings

The form under the settings tab is the exact same form that you used when you created an account. You can use this form to change your email, password, notification settings, etc.

API Access Tokens

The data portal has an API (application programming interface) which means any developer can create an app that can programmatically access the data in the portal data and use it for their own purpose. For example, think of all of the weather apps that are out there. There are only a few services that actually track the weather and these apps use an API to get the weather and then show it in some unique way that their users will like.

In order to use the data portal API, you must create an access token so that UNICEF knows who is using the API. To get an access token, simply click on red Get API Access Token button.

After you click on this button, your access token will appear in a table below the button.

Now that you have an access token, please refer to the API documentation on how to make API calls.

Next Steps

Below are links to other guides in the User Account guide book:

  • Create Account
